today on hot thai kitchen 
we are making a Thai omelet

Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today's 
recipe is probably going to be the simplest

thing I will ever show you on hot thai kitchen 
but I wanted to show it to you anyway because

it's got cultural importance we're making a Thai 
omelette or what we call kai jiew and it's got

cultural importance because it's what I consider 
the National go-to dish in desperate times and

here's what I mean when we have no money we make 
kai jiew when we've got no cooking skills we make kai jiew

when we've got nothing left in the pantry we make 
kai jiew because there were two things type you will

have in their kitchen it's eggs and fish sauce 
and those are the only two things that go into

this omelette at the very basic level but it is as 
delicious as it is simple so let's go two eggs and

a teaspoon of fish sauce okay room-temperature 
eggs work best for this because when you drop

it in the pan then the pan temperature doesn't 
drop too low and we really really want hot oil

for this ask an teaspoon of fish sauce and then 
you want to beat it really really well now this

is not ready yet which means when I lift it up 
there's gloopy bits of egg white so that's not

ready okay okay so this is good when I lift my 
fork it runs pretty smoothly if you are making

this for a non fish sauce eating person you can 
also do soy sauce or even oyster sauce anything

that will give it a little salty character some 
people like to put white pepper you can do that

as well but I want to keep it very very simple 
hey let's go fry it so when you are making Kai

do you want to use a round bottom wok or a small 
saute pan because you want to be able to control

sort of the size of your egg if you have if 
you use a flat bottom wok or really large

saute pan your egg will spread everywhere just 
be harder to flip now I'm going to show you two

different ways to do this the first way uses a 
lot of oil you basically be frying the eggs but

the egg will come out looking nicer and prettier 
and browned and bubbly the second way uses very

little oil so it's a healthier way to do it it's 
the way that I do it more often and I'm guessing

you're going to be doing that more often too so 
there's just two different options just you know

up to you you want the oil hot hot hot hot some 
people wait until the oil actually smokes but I

don't want to do that because smoking oil is 
bad for you I drop in a little bit of egg and

then if it suddenly does that right away then 
you're ready more or less anyway okay you ready

yeah and you're basically waiting for the egg to 
brown on the underside okay when it's crispy and

brown on the underside which does not take that 
long a little bit more see how cool that looks

it's like funnel cake yeah look how pretty that is 
now don't get too excited that the whole puffiness

will disappear as soon as you take it out like a 
fallen souffle but that's okay okay so the other

side really doesn't need to cook much because 
you're not going to see it so you don't need to

brown it so just to sort of set the other side 
and then you're done okay kaity Oh method two

I'm using a small saute pan but you can also just 
use a wok but you want this one to have a nonstick

surface whether it's a well-seasoned wok or just a 
non-stick pan so a little bit of oil I'm actually

going to pour some of this out it's supposed to 
be the healthier way right and then in goes the

egg okay and now since the only contact surface 
is where the egg touches the pan you want to keep

pushing and allowing the runny egg to run to the 
bottom and make contact with the pan so that way

the egg will set more quickly and cook evenly the 
egg actually ends up being a little more tender

texture wise this way because you know it's a 
little more gentle with the cooking and so I've

got heat on medium now just because I want to 
make sure the the top part of the egg has time

to set before I flip it make sure it's nice and 
golden brown oh this is unlike French omelette

where you want no browning whatsoever hi omelette 
you want to you know you want to have some nice

color going on okay it's almost there still little 
oh no I broke it make sure it's loose here we go
and that's it and you just want to let it cook for

literally a few seconds to set the 
other side and then slide it out

on to come on now eggie unto his people 
it's not cooperating there you go tada

so as you can see side by side this one's the 
one we kind of deep-fried it and it's got these

nice crispy bubbly edges yum yum yum yum crispy 
but uses a lot of oil this one is easier to make

it doesn't look as cool doesn't have the crispy 
edges the egg is a little more tender so it's

up to you kind of what you want let me show you 
how you can eat it you must must must I'm going

to eat the healthy one have it with some hot 
jasmine rice they're actually selling these

on the streets now so if you're in Thailand you 
might want to look for it and you must you must

you must have it with the original Thai Sirit 
a sauce which I've talked about before it's the

sauce from which the [ __ ] Brand serie ciao sauce 
originated hmm by the way this is what the bottle

looks like but recently somebody sent me one that 
looks like this which is a squeeze bottle it's

a little easier to use I haven't seen it on the 
market yet but you'll be it on the lookout for it

it's such comfort food like I just miss mommy you 
and I eat kaity oh so I hope you get a chance to

try it it's so simple so easy and it's eggs like
